awd_titl_txt: Geometry, Topology, and Rank One Lattices
awd_abstract_narration:
Lattices in Lie groups are a wide-sweeping generalization of the integers inside the real numbers. The deep connections between the integers and a broad range of mathematical areas from geometry to number theory have direct analogues for lattices in Lie groups, and the way in which lattices in Lie groups sit at the interface of so many fields has made them of fundamental importance since the late 19th century. The primary motivation for this project is to deepen our understanding of these connections. There is a special class of lattices that are called "arithmetic", where the connections to number theory are particularly strong, and this an overarching goal of this project is to use techniques from dynamics and geometry to understand when a lattice is arithmetic, and moreover deepen our understanding of the geometric consequences of arithmeticity. The project provides summer support for graduate students allowing them time for research and collaboration.

More specifically, this project aims to understand the geometry and topology of locally symmetric spaces, particularly real and complex hyperbolic manifolds, inspired by the fundamental problems in low-dimensional topology and geometric group theory that have dominated the fields since the pivotal work of Thurston and Gromov. On the one hand, it is of significant interest to learn the extent to which the Gromov-Thurston program pushes into this more general setting. More importantly, the questions studied in dimensions 2 and 3 for the last forty years are closely related to classical problems about discrete subgroups of Lie groups, and real and complex hyperbolic lattices are precisely the cases where many of the basic questions remain open, e.g., Betti numbers and problems related to (non)arithmeticity.  Particular problems to be studied include geometric characterizations of arithmeticity, analogues of the Margulis superrigidity theorem in rank one, and understanding complex hyperbolic lattices using techniques from algebraic geometry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported the discovery of several important new mathematical results, proved by the PI, his collaborators, and his graduate students.

A totally geodesic submanifold Y of a manifold X is a broad generalization of a line in the Euclidean plane, a flat plane in 3-dimensional Euclidean space, or a great circle on a sphere: Y contains a (locally) distance-minimizing path between any two points on it. Arithmetic manifolds are important objects that appear in differential geometry (as fundamental examples of manifolds with constant curvature -1), number theory, and algebraic geometry (as solutions to moduli problems). While they are first and foremost differential-geometric objects, their definition requires significant input from number theory. Solving a long-standing open problem, the PI and his collaborators gave a completely geometric characterization of arithmetic manifolds: a locally symmetric manifold of finite volume either has no totally geodesic submanifolds of dimension at least two (where those that are arithmetic are completely classified), else it has infinitely many maximal ones if and only if it is arithmetic. For example, a compact four-dimensional manifold admitting a complete metric of constant curvature -1 is arithmetic if and only if it contains infinitely many totally geodesic 3-manifolds.

The PI's PhD students, supported as research assistants during this award, also used hyperbolic knot theory to give the first examples of finite-volume 3-manifolds of constant curvature -1 that contain exactly one totally geodesic submanifold. Moreover, they gave the first examples known to have exactly k such submanifolds for any k > 0. Follow-up work classified all totally geodesic submanifolds in over half of the hyperbolic knot complements with at most 9 crossings.


Algebraic geometry is broadly the study of systems of polynomial equations. In algebraic geometry, one often distinguishes between objects using numerical invariants like the Euler characteristic. During this award, the PI also gave a refinement of the classification of so-called fake projective planes, which are varieties for whom most of the standard numerical invariants do not distinguish them from the most fundamental complex projective surface: the complex projective plane. Given a variety that is the zero locus of polynomials of several variables, one can additionaly apply any automorphism of the complex numbers to the coefficients to get a new variety. It is known that there are 100 fake projective planes up to isomorphism, and they fall into 50 classes up to complex conjugation (switching x+iy with x-iy for each coefficient of each variable). The PI refined this to prove that up to any automorphism of the complex numbers, there are exactly 46 fake projective planes.


Another major achievement during this project was the construction, joint with Domingo Toledo, of the first examples of smooth complex projective varieties in dimension at least four that are not locally symmetric and that admit a complete metric of negative curvature. This solved a problem that had been open for over 40 years, since Mostow and Siu famously published 2-dimensional examples in 1980.


The broader impacts of this award include the continued organization of the Temple Graduate Student Conference in Algebra, Geometry, and Topology, jointly with David Futer. This annual conference, run by Temple graduate students with faculty guidance, exposes graduate students in algebra, geometry, and topology to current research, and provides them with opportunities to present and discuss their own work. It also intends to provide a forum for graduate students to engage with each other as well as expert faculty members in their areas of research. All talks at the conference, except four given by distinguished keynote speakers, are given by graduate students. In organizing the conference, this is a truly unique opportunity for graduate students to learn about important aspects of being a professional mathematician that are not part of any standard curriculum. Faculty organizers work hard to involve the students in as much of the organization as possible, including plenary invitations and student talk selection, and teaching them about the grant writing process.


Through participant support, the PI also supported a small, intense week-long graduate-student collaborative mini-workshop at Temple on character varieties. Broader impacts also included RA support for one student studying to pass qualifying exams and two PhD students advancing their research. Two of the three supported students are from underrepresented groups in mathematics. Finally, the PI continued to develop inquiry-based courses, including Honors Calculus III (moreover, adapted for pandemic online-learning) and a graduate course on dynamical systems.
